SC seeks ways to improve social entertainment
New, stricter attendance policy incorporated into Council by-laws
by Tom McNamara
Discussion on social programming occupied much of the Student Council's time
at Wednesday's meeting.
Council President Scott FitzGerald announced that a "Fall Festival,"
scheduled for Sunday, October 11, and intended as student programming for Fall
Break, has been approved by the Office of
the Dean of Students.
He said that the event, to be held on the
Upper Quad from 1 to 7 p.m., will feature
sets by the Young Caucasians and as many
as three student bands. Arrangements with
the latter are "tentative."
John DiLeo, director of the Hopkins
Organization for Programming, said that
events would be free and that food and beer
will be sold. At last week's Council
meeting, procedures for enforcing legal
drinking age requirements at the beer
booth were discussed.
Last week's News-Letter reported that
approval for this event would be decided
by the University President's office.

FitzGerald said at Wednesday's meeting
that Council members who made that statement last Wednesday had expressed uncertainty and that the President's office was
not involved in the decision.
Initial plans for an "International
Festival" to be held the first week in
November were presented by Festival
Chairpersons Thao La and Erick Santos.
La said that one purpose of the celebration
is to promote racial and ethnic tolerance
in the University community.
According to Santos, the event will be
an expansion of an event held last year.
La said that "this year, there are more
clubs participating, "and that "each group
is going to get a singer or a performer"
to provide entertainment at some point during the festival.
The final major social event was discussed in response to junior class plans for a
happy hour observance to be held on campus each week.
DiLeo mentioned that the HOP already
has plans for such an activity and is waiting
for approval from the administration, but

is "looking for co-sponsors. The first one
should be a week from Friday. . .as soon
as we get official clearance, we can start
publicizing it."
The event is planned for "every Friday
afternoon" if it is approved, added DiLeo.
Also at the meeting:
OCouncil passed a version of the attendance policy discussed at the last two
meetings, incorporating it into the
organization's by-laws. Starting next
Wednesday, Council members who amass
three unexcused absences can be placed
before the students for a vote of
impeachment.
Vice President Stephanie Weissman
pointed out that regardless of the result of
such votes, the procedure may "be a deterrent" since the issue "will go before the
whole school" if Council so chooses.
The measure was passed 11 to 2, with
three members abstaining. Senior Class
President Sa Surmeli and Senior Class
Representative Damien Doute opposed the
amendment, calling it unnecessary.
In order to be classed as "excused," a

representative must report an absence in
advance to an executive member of the
Council, and the Council must approve the
excuse. Exceptions to the advance-notice
rule will be permitted occasionally.
ElDoute asked Weissman how the
members of the Committee on Committees
had been chosen, who was chosen, and
who was interviewed for the positions.
Weissman explained that the procedure set
down in the Council's constitution had
been followed when members were
selected at the end of last semester. Doute
said that he had not been aware of this process at the time.

almost nothing went on on this campus.
That's not supposed to happen." He charged Council members with making sure that
programming is planned for students. Several members mentioned that fraternities
are not obeying rules that should prevent
them from scheduling their parties on the
nights of most on-campus events.

Sustaining The Symposium
The MSE Symposium has shown consistent excellence over the last few years. The
chairmen have worked hard to attend to two
concerns: thoroughly addressing the topic
and enhancing the Symposium's reputation.
The advantages of the latter are that it improves the Symposium for years to come
and generates prestige for undergraduate
studies at Hopkins.
This year, the chairmen, Salman Azhar
and Shaun Mitchell, have proved to be no
exception. For their topic, politics and the
media, they have found a balance in which
they have drawn public 'big names' so as
to give the Symposium greater exposure
and have stayed within their budget in the
process. Equally important, it appears that
they have managed this without sacrificing
a fairly comprehensive look at the topic,
which is much to their credit.
The arduous process of securing speakers
was, as it is always, exacerbated by the confines of their allocated budget. The budget,
while nominally not insignificant, simply
does not even begin to cover the asking
prices for many public figures while working through normal agency channels.
This is especially true for a topic for
which figures in both politics and the media
would be recruited. Azhar and Mitchell
snagged McFarlane and Will through
Hopkins affiliations, though still at the expense of their entire allocation.
The Symposium, however, is not without
its limitations. Because of its budget, there
are only four speakers total. Azhar and Mitchell are still searching for one more.
Nevertheless, even if one is found, this

speaker's honorarium will have to financed by fund-raising, which so far has been
most unsuccessful.
Four speakers will impart less information and fewer percpectives on the issue
than it deserves. It is also unfortunate that
the number of speakers was necessarily
fewer than the six of last year, and ten of
the year before; three years ago, the symposium chairmen could only afford three
speakers.
That there are only four speakers places
a special burden on the Symposium. It must
continue to offer as wide a breadth of opinion as possible—and yet only four
speakers will be contributing.
Unfortunate in this regard is that the two
'big name' speakers, McFarlane and Will,
are both conservatives. In the public eye,
this conservative bias can detract from the
respectability the Symposium chairmen
have worked so hard to gain. It is important that future Symposia provide as much
diversity as possible by seeing that all concerned interest groups are represented.
Considering the rates of honoraria, simply throwing more money into the budget is
not the only answer. There is no doubt,
however, that it would help.
It would also help to select Symposia
chairmen ealier. This would provide the
chairmen with more time, and thus a better chance of approaching potential
speakers before their schedules have filled.,
The Symposium should continue to be a
distinguished forum for topical discussion.
Its standards should not be lessened when
this could be avoided by ample funding.

Calling to Council
This year's Student Council is getting off
to quite a slow start. Although a few different social programs are in the planning
stages, it appears that the Council's biggest
concern lately has been their own attendance policy.
It is no doubt critical for the Council to
have solid, regular attendance at their
meetings. As with any such organization,
each member contributes to the overall efficiency of the group. In addition, it is
necessary to have a quorum for voting
purposes.
However, little else has been accomplished at these meetings so far this year. This
week, Council President Scott FitzGerald
announced that the Office of the Dean of
Students has approved a "Fall Festival" to
be held the weekend of Fall Break. An "International Festival", planned for early
November, was also discussed. Both are
solid programs, but neither is anything
we've never seen before.
In a News-Letter interview last February,
FitzGerald said that it was his goal to focus
more on social programming as well as
community service in the Hopkins area. But
neither of these issues, beyond the Festival
plans, have yet been addressed in Council
meetings.
Last year at this time Council had
organized a freshman forum which inform-

ed students about security at Homewood
and in the surrounding area. The issue of
security resurfaced a number of times at last
year's Council meetings: the group spent
much time discussing the problems with the
security van service. Perhaps it was this
ongoing debate which led to the University's purchase of a second escort van.
The year's Council needs to address major issues such as this. Certainly there are
still problems with security— much of the
campus, for example, is inadequately lit.
Council also must come up with adequate
social programming for the semester. At
this week's meeting, some members said
that a number of fraternities are disobeying rules which prevent them from holding
parties during scheduled campus events.
FitzGerald suggested that Social Committee members should "call the frats and tell
them not to have a party." Perhaps a more
viable technique would be explicit coordinated efforts at programming between
university-sponsored social committees and
fraternities.
The Student Council has the potential to
be a most influential campus group. Its
members should look beyond the prepara- •
tion of attendance policies and begin to examine issues of importance for the entire
campus.

Last Saturday, Haverford and
Johns Hopkins met here in
Baltimore in an extremely important soccer game. The winner
would be in contcol in the MAC
and probaNy become one of the
front-rUnners for a NCAA
Southern Region Tournament
bid. For Hopkins, the game
would provide a chance for them
to relieve early season woes and
defeat a prominent team. Surely,
both teams would hustle, fight,
and do everything they could for
a victory.
The Blue Jays set the pace early and were the first to light the
scoreboard. Grenville Jones and
Joe DalPorto consistently beat the
visitors to the ball in an attempt
to generate some early offense.
Jones's efforts finally paid off as
he hustled to pick up a loose ball
which was deflected by the
Haverford goalie, but Jim
McKiernan was right there to
boot the rebound into the open
net. So at 3:26 of the first half,
Hopkins held a 1-0 wad.
The rest of the first half saw
Haverford beginning to control
the ball, but they weren't able to
do anything with it. The visitors
consistently made poor passes
flying over the football goalposts
or simply out of bounds. It may
have been a slight case of nervousness, but more likely, it was
the harassing of the Blue Jay
defense which gave Haverford
difficulty.

Hopkins consistently hustled on
defense, led by Staunton Golding
and Matt Lawrence. Lawrence, it
seemed, was always in the way
when Haverford mounted an offensive surge, and he helped
make goalie Eric Shaw's life a lot
easier. The strong Hooter defense
continued into the second half, as
Haverford continued to control
the ball. As the game progressed, it became increasingly obvious that the visitors were taken
out of thir game plan by the extremely physical Blue Jays.
Hopkins players were issued four
yellow cards and a red card, and
would have received far more if
the referee had paid attention to
the constant whining of the
Haverford players. Although the
Hooters couldn't manage much
offense, they clearly had the
visitors rattled.
At 17:37 of the second half,
Rob Shaker broke free in the
Hopkins zone for Haverford. He
got away with pushing off the
defender, and tied the game by
beating Shaw one-on-one. Shaw
remained under constant
pressure, and it appeared that the
Hopkins defense might finally be
getting tired. However, a saving
header by Craig Weinstein and a
beautiful play by Eric Lindenbaum preserved the tie, and the
teams entered overtime with a
score of 1-1.

to the occasion. The senior goalie
made four of five incredible saves

to keep the score unchanged, and
after two overtimes, the game
ended in a 1-1 time with much of
the crowd clamoring for a shootout.
So, it would appear that many
questions were left unanswered.
Or were they? Hopkins certainly
proved that they have fully
recovered from their early season
difficulties, and the defense was
simply awesome. Coach John
Haus proved his ability to inspire
a team, as his Blue Jays physically abused and out-hustled Haverford. Mostly, the Hooters reaffirmed that they are one of the
finest teams in the MAC and in
the Southern Region.
York College became the unfortunate victim of any Hopkins
frustration, as the Blue Jays
crushed them in Pennsylvania by
a score of 4-0. Four players accounted for all of the Hopkins
scoring in a rather neat fashion:
Warren Jones from Jim Roros,
Grenville Jones from Weinstein,
Weinstein from W. Jones, and
Roros from G. Jones. The
defense chalked up their third
shutout of the season.

record of 4-2-1. they travel to
Ursinus for a MAC game tomorrow, and then return home the
following Saturday to face
Dickinson at 10:45 in the morning. They will have to wait until
the post season to face Haverford
again, as the two teams are not
scheduled to meet again in the
regular season.

Sustaining The Symposium
The MSE Symposium has shown consistent excellence over the last few years. The
chairmen have worked hard to attend to two
concerns: thoroughly addressing the topic
and enhancing the Symposium's reputation.
The advantages of the latter are that it improves the Symposium for years to come
and generates prestige for undergraduate
studies at Hopkins.
This year, the chairmen, Salman Azhar
and Shaun Mitchell, have proved to be no
exception. For their topic, politics and the
media, they have found a balance in which
they have drawn public 'big names' so as
to give the Symposium greater exposure
and have stayed within their budget in the
process. Equally important, it appears that
they have managed this without sacrificing
a fairly comprehensive look at the topic,
which is much to their credit.
The arduous process of securing speakers
was, as it is always, exacerbated by the confines of their allocated budget. The budget,
while nominally not insignificant, simply
does not even begin to cover the asking
prices for many public figures while working through normal agency channels.
This is especially true for a topic for
which figures in both politics and the media
would be recruited. Azhar and Mitchell
snagged McFarlane and Will through
Hopkins affiliations, though still at the expense of their entire allocation.
The Symposium, however, is not without
its limitations. Because of its budget, there
are only four speakers total. Azhar and Mitchell are still searching for one more.
Nevertheless, even if one is found, this

speaker's honorarium will have to financed by fund-raising, which so far has been
most unsuccessful.
Four speakers will impart less information and fewer percpectives on the issue
than it deserves. It is also unfortunate that
the number of speakers was necessarily
fewer than the six of last year, and ten of
the year before; three years ago, the symposium chairmen could only afford three
speakers.
That there are only four speakers places
a special burden on the Symposium. It must
continue to offer as wide a breadth of opinion as possible—and yet only four
speakers will be contributing.
Unfortunate in this regard is that the two
'big name' speakers, McFarlane and Will,
are both conservatives. In the public eye,
this conservative bias can detract from the
respectability the Symposium chairmen
have worked so hard to gain. It is important that future Symposia provide as much
diversity as possible by seeing that all concerned interest groups are represented.
Considering the rates of honoraria, simply throwing more money into the budget is
not the only answer. There is no doubt,
however, that it would help.
It would also help to select Symposia
chairmen ealier. This would provide the
chairmen with more time, and thus a better chance of approaching potential
speakers before their schedules have filled.,
The Symposium should continue to be a
distinguished forum for topical discussion.
Its standards should not be lessened when
this could be avoided by ample funding.

Calling to Council
This year's Student Council is getting off
to quite a slow start. Although a few different social programs are in the planning
stages, it appears that the Council's biggest
concern lately has been their own attendance policy.
It is no doubt critical for the Council to
have solid, regular attendance at their
meetings. As with any such organization,
each member contributes to the overall efficiency of the group. In addition, it is
necessary to have a quorum for voting
purposes.
However, little else has been accomplished at these meetings so far this year. This
week, Council President Scott FitzGerald
announced that the Office of the Dean of
Students has approved a "Fall Festival" to
be held the weekend of Fall Break. An "International Festival", planned for early
November, was also discussed. Both are
solid programs, but neither is anything
we've never seen before.
In a News-Letter interview last February,
FitzGerald said that it was his goal to focus
more on social programming as well as
community service in the Hopkins area. But
neither of these issues, beyond the Festival
plans, have yet been addressed in Council
meetings.
Last year at this time Council had
organized a freshman forum which inform-

ed students about security at Homewood
and in the surrounding area. The issue of
security resurfaced a number of times at last
year's Council meetings: the group spent
much time discussing the problems with the
security van service. Perhaps it was this
ongoing debate which led to the University's purchase of a second escort van.
The year's Council needs to address major issues such as this. Certainly there are
still problems with security— much of the
campus, for example, is inadequately lit.
Council also must come up with adequate
social programming for the semester. At
this week's meeting, some members said
that a number of fraternities are disobeying rules which prevent them from holding
parties during scheduled campus events.
FitzGerald suggested that Social Committee members should "call the frats and tell
them not to have a party." Perhaps a more
viable technique would be explicit coordinated efforts at programming between
university-sponsored social committees and
fraternities.
The Student Council has the potential to
be a most influential campus group. Its
members should look beyond the prepara- •
tion of attendance policies and begin to examine issues of importance for the entire
campus.

cooks in front. After much
humiliation, they finally
understood.
"What you really want is a
hoagie!" said the cook.
"A sub!" said a geek behind
me.

wanted was a grinder.

Last Saturday, Haverford and
Johns Hopkins met here in
Baltimore in an extremely important soccer game. The winner
would be in contcol in the MAC
and probaNy become one of the
front-rUnners for a NCAA
Southern Region Tournament
bid. For Hopkins, the game
would provide a chance for them
to relieve early season woes and
defeat a prominent team. Surely,
both teams would hustle, fight,
and do everything they could for
a victory.
The Blue Jays set the pace early and were the first to light the
scoreboard. Grenville Jones and
Joe DalPorto consistently beat the
visitors to the ball in an attempt
to generate some early offense.
Jones's efforts finally paid off as
he hustled to pick up a loose ball
which was deflected by the
Haverford goalie, but Jim
McKiernan was right there to
boot the rebound into the open
net. So at 3:26 of the first half,
Hopkins held a 1-0 wad.
The rest of the first half saw
Haverford beginning to control
the ball, but they weren't able to
do anything with it. The visitors
consistently made poor passes
flying over the football goalposts
or simply out of bounds. It may
have been a slight case of nervousness, but more likely, it was
the harassing of the Blue Jay
defense which gave Haverford
difficulty.

Hopkins consistently hustled on
defense, led by Staunton Golding
and Matt Lawrence. Lawrence, it
seemed, was always in the way
when Haverford mounted an offensive surge, and he helped
make goalie Eric Shaw's life a lot
easier. The strong Hooter defense
continued into the second half, as
Haverford continued to control
the ball. As the game progressed, it became increasingly obvious that the visitors were taken
out of thir game plan by the extremely physical Blue Jays.
Hopkins players were issued four
yellow cards and a red card, and
would have received far more if
the referee had paid attention to
the constant whining of the
Haverford players. Although the
Hooters couldn't manage much
offense, they clearly had the
visitors rattled.
At 17:37 of the second half,
Rob Shaker broke free in the
Hopkins zone for Haverford. He
got away with pushing off the
defender, and tied the game by
beating Shaw one-on-one. Shaw
remained under constant
pressure, and it appeared that the
Hopkins defense might finally be
getting tired. However, a saving
header by Craig Weinstein and a
beautiful play by Eric Lindenbaum preserved the tie, and the
teams entered overtime with a
score of 1-1.
Haverford dominated the overtime periods, but Eric Shaw rose
to the occasion. The senior goalie
made four of five incredible saves

to keep the score unchanged, and
after two overtimes, the game
ended in a 1-1 time with much of
the crowd clamoring for a shootout.
So, it would appear that many
questions were left unanswered.
Or were they? Hopkins certainly
proved that they have fully
recovered from their early season
difficulties, and the defense was
simply awesome. Coach John
Haus proved his ability to inspire
a team, as his Blue Jays physically abused and out-hustled Haverford. Mostly, the Hooters reaffirmed that they are one of the
finest teams in the MAC and in
the Southern Region.
York College became the unfortunate victim of any Hopkins
frustration, as the Blue Jays
crushed them in Pennsylvania by
a score of 4-0. Four players accounted for all of the Hopkins
scoring in a rather neat fashion:
Warren Jones from Jim Roros,
Grenville Jones from Weinstein,
Weinstein from W. Jones, and
Roros from G. Jones. The
defense chalked up their third
shutout of the season.
The Hooters now boast a
record of 4-2-1. they travel to
Ursinus for a MAC game tomorrow, and then return home the
following Saturday to face
Dickinson at 10:45 in the morning. They will have to wait until
the post season to face Haverford
again, as the two teams are not
scheduled to meet again in the
regular season.
